title: 107_hr2512
content: Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border. Authorization of appropriations for enhanced border investigative resources on the Southwest border, including funds for salaries, expenses, and equipment for the United States Customs Service. This includes specific allocations for narcotics enforcement, cargo processing, and counterterrorism technology deployment, such as mobile truck gamma ray systems and high energy pallet gamma ray systems. The funding allocation for enhanced border investigative resources on the Southwest border includes $4.6 million for mobile truck gamma ray systems, $26.6 million for high energy pallet gamma ray systems, $24.3 million for higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, $41.3 million for nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, $12 million for nonintrusive inspection technology maintenance, and various other allocations for canine kennel construction, replacement of canines, x-ray vans, tool trucks, contraband detection kits, and surveillance camera systems. The funding allocation for border investigative resources includes various equipment such as contraband detection kits, surveillance camera systems, truck license plate reader systems, narcotics particle detectors, vehicle targeting systems, under vehicle inspection systems, and radiation detection devices. In fiscal years after 2002, $15,832,000 is allocated annually for equipment maintenance and personnel training related to radiation detection devices. The Commissioner of Customs can use funds for technologically superior equipment that achieves similar results at the same or lower cost as specified equipment. In fiscal years after 2002, funds can be reallocated for equipment specified in subsection (b) to achieve similar results at a lower cost. Additionally, $79,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and $172,000,000 in fiscal year 2003 are allocated for increased staffing in Southwest border enforcement. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, funds are allocated for increased staffing at Southwest border ports of entry to reduce waiting times, intensify efforts against drug smuggling, and improve infrastructure. Additionally, funds are available for construction, improvement, and expansion of Customs Service facilities at ports of entry on the Southwest Border. Amounts authorized for the United States Customs Service are in addition to any other appropriations by law.
